intro: Scorpiurus subvillosus var. acutifolius, commonly known as the hairy false nettle, is a flowering plant native to parts of North America. It is a member of the Urticaceae family, which includes stinging nettles, and features small, green, heart-shaped leaves with fine hairs. The plant produces tiny, pale yellow flowers that are clustered in umbels, typical of the genus Scorpiurus. It thrives in moist, disturbed soils and is often found in woodland edges or along stream banks. Its botanical characteristics make it identifiable by its hairy foliage and clustered inflorescences.
